text.p: Burlington Northern and Santa Fe Corp on Thursday said it agreed to buy 405 locomotives from General Motors Corp's Electro-Motive Division and General Electric Corp's GE Transportation Systems.
Some of the equipment will be delivered on an accelerated schedule beginning this year, Burlington said.

The railroad said it ordered 26 EMD SD75I locomotives to be delivered in 1997 and 105 EMD SD70MAC locomotives for delivery in 1997 and 1998. The remaining 104 EMD locomotives will be delivered in 1999 and 2000.

GM's EMD SD70MAC locomotives each generate 4,000 horsepower, using alternating current traction motors. All three models have electronic brakes and either distributed power capabilities or future provisions for distributed power.

Burlington spokesman Michael Martin said the 105 SD70MACS from GM were for coal train service and to haul other bulk commodities, while the 26 SD75Is were for such intermodal traffic as containers and truck trailers.
He said the GE 170s would have a variety of uses, including intermodal general freight in box, tank and hopper cars.
Martin declined to discuss what the railroad was paying for the locomotives.

Burlington Northern Santa Fe operates one of the largest railroads in North America, with 35,000 route miles of track in 29 states and two Canadian provinces. That includes 7,900 miles of trackage rights, which permit the railway to operate its trains with its crews over another railroad's tracks.
